Line 25: Line 25:
The NDP enjoyed uncontested power in state politics, usually considered a ''de facto'' [[single party]] with [[authoritarian]] characteristics inside an officially [[multi-party system]],<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11961685 BBC News]</ref><ref>Jason Brownlee âAuthoritarianism in an age of democratizationâ, p. 124</ref><ref>[http://carnegieendowment.org/publications/index.cfm?fa=view&id=35629 Marina Ottoway: Egypt: From Semi-Authoritarianism to One-Dimensionality]</ref><ref>[http://www.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-476/_nr-1431/i.html Qantara.de]</ref> from its creation until the resignation of Sadat's successor [[Hosni Mubarak]] in response to the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]].
The NDP enjoyed uncontested power in state politics, usually considered a ''de facto'' [[single party]] with [[authoritarian]] characteristics inside an officially [[multi-party system]],<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11961685 BBC News]</ref><ref>Jason Brownlee âAuthoritarianism in an age of democratizationâ, p. 124</ref><ref>[http://carnegieendowment.org/publications/index.cfm?fa=view&id=35629 Marina Ottoway: Egypt: From Semi-Authoritarianism to One-Dimensionality]</ref><ref>[http://www.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-476/_nr-1431/i.html Qantara.de]</ref> from its creation until the resignation of Sadat's successor [[Hosni Mubarak]] in response to the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]].
â
The National Democratic Party was an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] [[centrism|centrist]] party<ref name=nel6/><ref>{{citenews|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/2010/11/201011211241793913.html|title=Has Egypt's ruling party grown fat? |work=[[Al-Jazeera]]|date=22 November 2010|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and the organical successor of the [[Arab Socialist Union]], the former ruling sole party since 1962, moderating its [[arab socialism]] ideology. NDP was a member of the [[Socialist International]] from 1989, until it was expelled in 2011, also in response to the revolution.<ref name=si>{{citenews|url=http://www.socialistinternational.org/images/dynamicImages/files/Letter%20NDP.pdf|work=[[Socialist International]]|title=To the General Secretary of the National Democratic Party, NDP|date=31 January 2011|location=[[Egypt]]|accessdate=2 February 2011|first=Luis|last=Ayala}}</ref>
+
The National Democratic Party was an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] [[centrism|centrist]] party<ref name=nel6/><ref name="aljazeera1"/> and the organical successor of the [[Arab Socialist Union]], the former ruling sole party since 1962, moderating its [[arab socialism]] ideology. NDP was a member of the [[Socialist International]] from 1989, until it was expelled in 2011, also in response to the revolution.<ref name=si>{{citenews|url=http://www.socialistinternational.org/images/dynamicImages/files/Letter%20NDP.pdf|work=[[Socialist International]]|title=To the General Secretary of the National Democratic Party, NDP|date=31 January 2011|location=[[Egypt]]|accessdate=2 February 2011|first=Luis|last=Ayala}}</ref>
â
It was dissolved on 16 April 2011 by court order, and its assets were transferred to the state.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13105044</ref>
+
It was dissolved on 16 April 2011 by court order, and its assets were transferred to the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13105044 |title=BBC News - Egypt: Mubarak's former ruling party dissolved by court |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-04-19}}</ref>
==Electoral system in Egypt==
==Electoral system in Egypt==
Line 119: Line 119:
Protests continued as planned, despite a government ban on demonstrations and an overnight [[curfew]] imposed. Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets. During the protests, the NDP headquarters in Cairo was set ablaze and destroyed.<ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptians losing fear of confrontation with regime|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12312330|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
Protests continued as planned, despite a government ban on demonstrations and an overnight [[curfew]] imposed. Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets. During the protests, the NDP headquarters in Cairo was set ablaze and destroyed.<ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptians losing fear of confrontation with regime|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12312330|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
â
On February 5, it was reported that Mubarak resigned as chairperson of the NDP, but it was later announced that "Al Arabiya television retracts its earlier report that Hosni Mubarak resigned", but his son Gamal and other top officials also resigned from its central committee. Hossam Badrawi, seen as a liberal, took over as secretary-general.<ref>http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests</ref>
+
On February 5, it was reported that Mubarak resigned as chairperson of the NDP, but it was later announced that "Al Arabiya television retracts its earlier report that Hosni Mubarak resigned", but his son Gamal and other top officials also resigned from its central committee. Hossam Badrawi, seen as a liberal, took over as secretary-general.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 5 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2011-02-04 |accessdate=2011-04-19}}</ref>
On February 11, less than a week after taking office, Hossam Badrawi resigned from the position and the party. It was the day Hosni Mubarak left office of the [[President of Egypt]].
On February 11, less than a week after taking office, Hossam Badrawi resigned from the position and the party. It was the day Hosni Mubarak left office of the [[President of Egypt]].
Line 126: Line 126:
Upon the resignation of the former President, a number of NDP officials and members have resigned following the filing of a number of lawsuits calling for its dissolution. On April 12th, and in what was considered a surprise move, [[Talaat Sadat]], nephew of former Egyptian President, [[Anwar Sadat]] who was not a party member and who have been long considered an opposition member was selected as the new chairman.
Upon the resignation of the former President, a number of NDP officials and members have resigned following the filing of a number of lawsuits calling for its dissolution. On April 12th, and in what was considered a surprise move, [[Talaat Sadat]], nephew of former Egyptian President, [[Anwar Sadat]] who was not a party member and who have been long considered an opposition member was selected as the new chairman.
â
Following his appointment, Mr. Sadat have issued multiple statements declaring his intent on "clean housing" the party from its corrupted officials and party members and that the party name would be changed to the '''"New National Party"''' to reflect the party's new age. The party have even declared that it will adopt the ideals and goals of the recent Egyptian revolution in its party platform. However, on April 16, 2011, the NDP party was dissolved by the court and its assets were ordered to be handed over to the government. <ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011416125051889315.html</ref>
+
Following his appointment, Mr. Sadat have issued multiple statements declaring his intent on "clean housing" the party from its corrupted officials and party members and that the party name would be changed to the '''"New National Party"''' to reflect the party's new age. The party have even declared that it will adopt the ideals and goals of the recent Egyptian revolution in its party platform. However, on April 16, 2011, the NDP party was dissolved by the court and its assets were ordered to be handed over to the government. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011416125051889315.html |title=Egypt dissolves former ruling party - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-04-19}}</ref>
